<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 262, 170, 278]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 286, 371, 301]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[745, 286, 861, 301]]<|/det|>
May/June 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[722, 310, 861, 325]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 338, 376, 353]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 365, 343, 380]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 397, 212, 412]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 413, 768, 533]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 560, 208, 574]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 575, 693, 606]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 68, 118, 84]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 98, 640, 533]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1\mathrm{u} = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 69, 160, 84]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 100, 530, 133]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^2\] \[\nu^2 = u^2 +2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 149, 505, 165]]<|/det|>
\[W = p\Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 172, 510, 203]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 212, 490, 229]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 235, 532, 266]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 275, 510, 291]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 308, 576, 343]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_0\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(x_0^2 - x^2)}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 348, 504, 381]]<|/det|>
\[f_0 = \frac{f_s\nu}{v\pm\nu_s}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 387, 510, 419]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 425, 593, 444]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_1 + 1 / C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 457, 564, 476]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_1 + C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 489, 504, 514]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 526, 504, 545]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 556, 564, 575]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 588, 593, 606]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 612, 504, 644]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 650, 530, 668]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 682, 546, 700]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 707, 504, 739]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 67, 667, 85]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 97, 94, 115]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 97, 141, 115]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 97, 806, 114]]<|/det|>
A property of a vector quantity, that is not a property of a scalar quantity, is direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 111, 584, 128]]<|/det|>
For example, velocity has direction but speed does not.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 141, 175, 159]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

scalar quantities: ............................................... and ......................................

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 244, 858, 262]]<|/det|>

1. ..........................................................................................................................

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 348, 876, 380]]<|/det|>
A ship at sea is travelling with a velocity of \(13\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) in a direction \(35^{\circ}\) east of north in still water, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 393, 695, 504]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 523, 507, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 555, 173, 572]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 555, 876, 586]]<|/det|>
Determine the magnitudes of the components of the velocity of the ship in the north and the east directions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 731, 876, 749]]<|/det|>
<form>north component of velocity = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 759, 876, 777]]<|/det|>
<form>east component of velocity = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 775, 876, 793]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 68, 173, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 67, 876, 101]]<|/det|>
The ship now experiences a tidal current. The water in the sea moves with a velocity of \(2.7 \text{m s}^{-1}\) to the west.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 111, 769, 129]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resultant velocity component of the ship in the east direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 214, 876, 233]]<|/det|>
<form>resultant east component of velocity = ............................................. $\text{ms}^{-1}$ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 244, 170, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 244, 876, 278]]<|/det|>
Use your answers in (b)(i) and (b)(ii) to determine the magnitude of the resultant velocity of the ship.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 420, 876, 440]]<|/det|>
<form>magnitude of resultant velocity = ................................................. $\text{ms}^{-1}$ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[138, 452, 173, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 451, 876, 484]]<|/det|>
Use your answers in (b)(i) and (b)(ii) to determine the angle between north and the resultant velocity of the ship.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[492, 640, 876, 658]]<|/det|>
<form>angle = ......................................................... Â° [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[794, 672, 876, 689]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<label>2</label>

<label>(a)</label>

Define acceleration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 127, 876, 144]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 156, 876, 189]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 521, 507, 540]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

Explain, with reference to forces acting on the stone, the shape of the curve in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 699, 875, 715]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 727, 173, 746]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 185, 665, 203]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows a type of balance that is used for measuring mass.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 212, 811, 395]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 412, 562, 430]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 456, 875, 488]]<|/det|>
A rigid rod is pivoted about a point \(6.2 \text{cm}\) from the centre of a pan which is attached to one end. The object being measured is placed on the centre of this pan.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 500, 875, 532]]<|/det|>
A spring, attached to the rod \(1.8 \text{cm}\) from the pivot, is attached at its other end to a fixed point P. The spring obeys Hooke's law over the full range of operation of the balance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 545, 875, 577]]<|/det|>
A pointer, on the other side of the pivot, is set against a millimetre scale which is a distance \(52.6 \text{cm}\) from the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 590, 875, 621]]<|/det|>
When the system is in equilibrium with no mass on the pan, the rod is horizontal and the pointer indicates a reading on the scale of \(86 \text{mm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 635, 875, 666]]<|/det|>
An object of mass \(0.472 \text{kg}\) is now placed on the pan. As a result, the pointer moves to indicate a reading of \(123 \text{mm}\) on the scale when the system is again in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 677, 173, 695]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 677, 769, 695]]<|/det|>
Show that the increase in the length of the spring is approximately \(1.3 \text{mm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 794, 876, 812]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 67, 175, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 67, 828, 85]]<|/det|>
Calculate the magnitude of the moment about the pivot of the weight of the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 214, 876, 232]]<|/det|>
<form>moment = .................................................... Nm [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 243, 173, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 243, 876, 276]]<|/det|>
Use your answer in (b)(ii) to determine the increase in the tension in the spring due to the \(0.472\mathrm{kg}\) mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 377, 876, 395]]<|/det|>
<form>increase in tension = ................................................. N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 406, 175, 425]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 406, 876, 438]]<|/det|>
Use the information in (b)(i) and your answer in (b)(iii) to determine the spring constant \(k\) of the spring. Give a unit with your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 583, 876, 600]]<|/det|>
<form>k = ............................................ unit ........... [2]

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 184, 826, 203]]<|/det|>
Two waves, with intensities \(I\) and \(4I\), superpose. The waves have the same frequency.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 214, 764, 232]]<|/det|>
Determine, in terms of \(I\), the maximum possible intensity of the resulting wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 348, 876, 365]]<|/det|>
<form>maximum intensity = .................................................... $I$

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 377, 876, 424]]<|/det|>
Coherent light of wavelength \(550 \text{nm}\) is incident normally on a double slit of slit separation \(0.35 \text{mm}\). A series of bright and dark fringes forms on a screen placed a distance of \(1.2 \text{m}\) from the double slit, as shown in Fig. 4.1. The screen is parallel to the double slit.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 435, 796, 630]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 648, 562, 666]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 67, 175, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 67, 850, 85]]<|/det|>
Determine the distance between the centres of adjacent bright fringes on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[472, 214, 876, 232]]<|/det|>
<form>distance = .................................................... m [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 243, 173, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 243, 798, 262]]<|/det|>
The light of wavelength \(550 \text{nm}\) is replaced with red light of a single frequency.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 273, 876, 306]]<|/det|>
State and explain the change, if any, in the distance between the centres of adjacent bright fringes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[801, 386, 876, 403]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[801, 408, 876, 426]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 68, 94, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 68, 139, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 67, 544, 85]]<|/det|>
Define the _electromotive force_ (e.m.f.) of a source.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[101, 191, 134, 208]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>
